Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Genomic signatures of pathogen-mediated selection in diachronic populations of the House Finch
Award.AbstractNarration:
This study will examine how the House Finch has evolved resistance and tolerance to a novel pathogen. Novel pathogens are a challenge faced by many species, and understanding how species might respond is integral for informing conservation efforts to protect global biodiversity. Human-mediated introductions of pathogens into new environments are common today given the ease of global travel. In 1994, a species of bacteria, Mycoplamsa gallisepticum, historically associated with poultry, infected the House Finch and killed an estimated 225 million individuals (60% of the eastern population). This pathogen is the cause of one of the most significant diseases of the poultry industry, so any genes identified as targets of evolution in this House Finchmay also be applicable to improving resistance and tolerance in poultry.

The project will use whole genome resequencing and genotyping of immune genes such as MHC and TLRs to disentangle the genetic underpinnings of two important immunological responses, resistance and tolerance. Data collected from wild populations around the U.S. in multiple time periods before and after exposure to the pathogen will show how the House Finch has evolved. The researchers will test whether MHC and TLR intra-individual allelic diversity has increased in response to strong selection, or if specific alleles confer resistance or susceptibility to the pathogen by increasing or decreasing in frequency over time. Genotyping of experimentally infected individuals from a historically unexposed population will test whether putatively selected alleles are associated with disease phenotypes such as pathogen load or conjunctival swelling.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The mandate of conservation biology is to preserve as much biodiversity as possible given our rapidly changing planet. Habitats are changing, animals and plants are being transported to new environments, and species are exposed to new diseases. To mitigate the effects of these disturbances, conservation biologists are turning to genomic tools to comprehensively understand the population structuring and genetic diversity of a species.

This DDIG funded project integrate geographic and temporal sampling to compare the impacts on genomic variability of recent founder events and an epizootic on the genome of the House Finch (Haeomorhous mexicanus), a common North American songbird with a well-documented and recent history of both introductions and disease. House Finches, native to the western US and Mexico, were introduced to the eastern US in 1940. Following substantial population expansions in both locations, in 1994, a bacterium, Mycoplasma gallisepticum (MG), previously associated with poultry, jumped to House Finches and caused severe declines across both introduced eastern and native western populations. Experimental infections have shown that House Finches evolved resistance and tolerance to the new disease within 10 years. The project makes use of a series of House Finch samples collected before the disease, 10 years after the disease, and 20 years after the disease. We apply whole-genome resequencing to understand both which genes are responsible for conferring resistance to the disease, and to understand how the disease may have affected genome-wide genetic variation. Specifically, the DDIG funding permitted the sequencing of House Finches 20 years after the disease, permitting the researchers to understand the longer-term consequences of the genomic changes resulting from the disease.

We show that the introduction to the eastern US had a larger genome-wide impact on patterns of genetic variation than the disease. There was a slight decline in genetic diversity following the disease, but House Finch dispersal mitigated these effects in the later time point. Analyses the specific regions of the genome responsible for House Finch resistance and tolerance are ongoing, and will be verified by sequencing those regions in individuals that have been part of previous experimental infections. The results of this project will not only provide insights that can help conservation biologists predict the consequences of anthropogenic disturbances, but will provide a rich dataset that will likely be useful for many projects in the future.

The DDIG contributed to substantial training for Co-PI Shultz, specifically in laboratory and bioinformatics training. Shultz has used these skills to train numerous other students both inside and outside of her department, including three female undergraduates, and one visiting female student who is an underrepresented minority in STEM fields. She is currently putting together a workshop on analyzing these types of data, which will be of interest to students and researchers from many different backgrounds. In addition to presentations at scientific meetings, Shultz also presented this research to groups of adults with no previous scientific training, and to a group of high school teachers to bring back to the classroom. Finally, Shultz started a video series to broadly share the results of this research with the broader community.
